DOCNAME: R. AND F. v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
TEXT: The first and second applicants , NORP and PERSON , are NORP nationals who were born in DATE and DATE respectively and live in GPE . They are represented before the ORG by Miss M Dyker , a lawyer practising in GPE .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .
The applicants met in DATE and started a relationship . They were married in DATE and have been living as a married couple since , jointly owning their home and having a joint mortgage .

The second applicant , PERSON , was born male , but underwent gender reassignment surgery ( funded by ORG ) in DATE , after a consultation process which began in DATE . The first applicant , NORP , was involved in this process throughout , attending appointments with the relevant medical professionals , and providing both practical and emotional support . The applicants contend that PERSON ’s treatment and surgery have not affected either the emotional or physical aspects of their relationship , and they have left open the possibility of having children in the future .

F wishes to have her new gender recognised . In particular , she wishes to have a birth certificate upon which her gender is recognised as female . By the provisions of LAW ( ‘ ORG ) , provision is made for those who have acquired a new gender to apply for a full ORG ( ‘ GRC’ ) . This in turn entitles the holder to obtain what is , to all outward intents and purposes , a new birth certificate recognising their new gender .

However , it is a condition of the issue of a full ORG that the recipient not be married . As she is married , PERSON is entitled to apply for an interim gender recognition certificate ( ‘ GRC’ ) to allow her female status to be officially recognised , but she would only be able to obtain a full ORG if she and NORP divorce , something to which they are deeply opposed .

ORG would necessarily incur costs of ORG together with solicitors’ costs of QUANTITY . Their representative before this ORG also notes that , in the event that NORP and PERSON were required to divorce , she would have to advise them to take independent legal advice with a view to coming to an agreement as to how they should divide their matrimonial property to protect their financial positions . The applicants contend that a failure to take such advice and divide the property accordingly would lead to NORP , in particular , losing rights . Taking independent legal advice and drawing up a minute of agreement ( even if it were not contentious ) would cost in the region of GBP CARDINAL for each party . There would also be costs associated with any resulting transfers of property for purposes of division : a sale of their property would incur legal costs of CARDINAL .

As of DATE , when the relevant sections of LAW entered into force , the applicants are entitled to enter a civil partnership . However , they do not consider such a partnership a full substitute for marriage . They highlight both what they contend is the different social standing attached to such civil partnerships and also the fact that they do not provide identical legal protection to that enshrined in statutes governing marriage . Entry into a civil partnership would also necessarily incur costs of in the region of GBP CARDINAL.CARDINAL .

LAW ( ‘ ORG ) provides a mechanism whereby transsexuals may have their new genders recognised . LAW provides that ORG must grant an application if it is satisfied that the applicant : ( CARDINAL ) has , or has had , gender dysphoria ; ( CARDINAL ) has lived in the acquired gender throughout DATE ; and ( CARDINAL ) intends to continue to live in the acquired gender until death .

By section CARDINAL , an application must include a report from a registered medical practitioner , or a chartered psychologist , either of whom must be practising in the field of gender dysphoria . This report must include details of diagnosis . A second report must also be included , which need not be from a medical professional practising in the field of gender dysphoria , but could be from any registered medical practitioner . CARDINAL of the reports must include details of any treatment that the applicant has undergone , is undergoing or that is prescribed or planned , for the purposes of modifying sexual characteristics .
Section CARDINAL sets down the consequences of an application being successful . It reads in material part as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) If a ORG grants an application under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) it must issue a gender recognition certificate to the applicant .
( CARDINAL ) Unless the applicant is married , the certificate is to be a full gender recognition certificate .
( CARDINAL ) If the applicant is married , the certificate is to be an interim gender recognition certificate .

( CARDINAL ) Schedule CARDINAL ( annulment or dissolution of marriage after issue of interim gender recognition certificate ) has effect [ this amends section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE so that a party can apply to the courts for a divorce on the basis of the issue of an interim gender recognition certificate to either party to the marriage ] .
Section CARDINAL governs the situation where an interim certificate has been granted . It reads in relevant part as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) A court which -
( b ) ( in GPE ) grants a decree of divorce on that ground ,
must , on doing so , issue a full gender recognition certificate to that party and send a copy to the Secretary of ORG .
( CARDINAL ) If an interim gender recognition certificate has been issued to a person and either-

( a ) the person ’s marriage is dissolved or annulled ( otherwise than on the ground mentioned in subsection ( CARDINAL ) ) in proceedings instituted during DATE beginning with DATE on which it was issued , or
( b ) the person ’s spouse dies within that period ,
the person may make an application for a full gender recognition certificate at any time within the period specified in subsection ( CARDINAL ) ( unless the person is again married ) .
( CARDINAL ) That period is the period of DATE beginning with the day on which the marriage is dissolved or annulled or the death occurs .

( CARDINAL ) An application under subsection ( CARDINAL ) must include evidence of the dissolution or annulment of the marriage and the date on which proceedings for it were instituted , or of the death of the spouse and the date on which it occurred .
( CARDINAL ) An application under subsection ( CARDINAL ) is to be determined by ORG .
( CARDINAL ) The Panel –
( a ) must grant the application if satisfied that the applicant is not married , and
( b ) otherwise must reject it .
( CARDINAL ) If the Panel grants the application it must issue a full gender recognition certificate to the applicant . ”
The only function of an interim gender recognition certificate is therefore to provide a document which can be used to obtain a divorce .
The other provisions of DATE only apply where a full gender recognition certificate is concerned . These include , for instance , section CARDINAL , which provides that :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Where a full gender recognition certificate is issued to a person , the person ’s gender becomes for all purposes the acquired gender ( so that , if the acquired gender is the male gender , the person ’s sex becomes that of a man and , if it is the female gender , the person ’s sex becomes that of a woman ) . ”

By Paragraph CARDINAL of Part CARDINAL of Schedule CARDINAL to the GRA CARDINAL , the issue of a full gender recognition certificate obliges the Registrar General for GPE to make an entry in the ( new ) ORG for GPE and to mark the original entry in the register of births referring to the birth ( or adoption ) of the transsexual person to show that the original entry has been superseded . Paragraph CARDINAL makes provision for an extract to be made of any entry in the ORG . An abbreviated certificate of birth compiled from the ORG must , by LAW , not disclose that it is compiled from the ORG . Both copies of and abbreviated certificates therefore look the same as any other birth certificates ; they therefore act , to all outward intents and purposes , as new birth certificates .

Not all provisions of the ORG require status or situations existing prior to gender recognition to be changed or dissolved . For instance , provisions as to parenthood ( section CARDINAL ) , succession ( section CARDINAL ) and peerages ( section CARDINAL ) explicitly provide that the person ’s gender has become the acquired gender does not effect their status or rights flowing therefrom .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(e ) of the Marriage ( GPE ) Act DATE provides that there is a legal impediment to a marriage in NORP law where the parties “ are of the same sex . ” The NORP position is considered to be broadly similar to that in GPE , where the relevant provision is contained in section CARDINAL(c ) of LAW DATE , which provides that a marriage is void unless the parties are “ respectively male and female . ”

In the NORP case of PERSON v PERSON [ DATE ] Probate Reports CARDINAL it was held that marriage could only be between a woman and a man , determined on genital , gonadal and chromosomal factors , and should not take into account the party ’s psychological beliefs , however genuine and profound .

Section CARDINAL(c ) of LAW DATE and PERSON v PERSON have recently been reconsidered by ORG in PERSON v PERSON [ DATE ] UKHL CARDINAL . Their Lordships considered that the words “ male ” and “ female ” were to be given their ordinary meaning and referred to a person ’s biological gender as determined at birth so that , for purposes of marriage , a person born with CARDINAL sex could not later become a person of the opposite sex . They therefore held that it was not possible under LANGUAGE ( and by analogy LANGUAGE ) law for a person to marry another person who was of the same gender at birth , even if one of them had undergone gender reassignment surgery . They did , however , issue a declaration that Section CARDINAL(c ) of the DATE Act represented a continuing obstacle to the ability of the ( male to female ) transsexual petitioner to enter into a valid marriage with a man , and that it was therefore incompatible with her rights under LAW .
The ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE , as amended by LAW , reads in relevant part as follows :
“ Section CARDINAL
( CARDINAL ) In an action for divorce the court may grant decree of divorce if , but only if , it is established in accordance with the following provisions of the LAW that –
( b ) an interim gender recognition certificate under LAW has , after the date of the marriage , been issued to either party to the marriage . ”

The ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE does not provide for any defence to divorce where it is sought on the basis of the issue of an interim gender recognition certificate . The LAW is to be amended by a PERSON currently before ORG , but it does not appear that any amendments that may be made by the PERSON are material to this section .

The financial consequences of divorce are set out in the ORG ( GPE ) Act DATE and LAW DATE . The rights on divorce are broadly speaking that the parties are DATE of the property referable to the period of the marriage , regardless of the name in which the property in question is formally held . Where no application is made for financial provision under LAW ( Scotland ) Act DATE , then the general law of property applies , such that parties may lose rights – for instance , property will continue to be held by the person in whose name it is held , even if that results in CARDINAL person having more property than another .

Other consequences of divorce include the loss of spousal rights under the LAW DATE , the loss of rights in relation to the matrimonial home under ORG ) ( GPE ) Act DATE , tax consequences such as the loss of spousal exemptions , and the loss of entitlement to pension or other benefits contingent on parties being married ( e.g. widow ’s benefits under ORG DATE ) . It may also lead to an inability to recover damages if the ex - spouse dies due to somebody else ’s fault by operation of Schedule CARDINAL to the Damages ( GPE ) Act DATE ( although this provision has not been the subject of judicial scrutiny since the passage of LAW DATE ) . Finally , certain rules of evidence , for instance that a spouse is not generally a compellable witness against another spouse ( under sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL Criminal Procedure ( GPE ) Act DATE ) , cease to have effect .

This LAW the CPA CARDINAL ) came into force on DATE . It has the effect of allowing same sex couples to acquire a legal status for their relationships , with legal rights and responsibilities . The LAW is to be amended with respect to GPE by LAW ( GPE ) PERSON , currently before ORG ; this will have the effect of increasing the rights of same sex cohabitants in GPE over and above those in force in GPE and GPE .

The provisions in DATE ( as amended as per LAW ( GPE ) Act DATE ) do not exactly mirror those applicable to marriages . For instance , the provisions for formation of civil partnerships do not entirely match those for civil ( i.e. not religious marriages ) contained in the Marriage ( Scotland ) Act DATE and subordinate legislation : there is , for instance , no equivalent to section CARDINALA of LAW , which preserves the validity of marriages which in their formation failed to comply with CARDINAL of the formal requirements imposed by that LAW .

On dissolution of a civil partnership , the LAW does not contain any provision requiring property relating to periods of marriage prior to civil partnership to be taken into account ( other than property bought for use as a family home or furniture or plenishings for the home , by an amendment to LAW DATE ) .
